title: Investment Basics: Stocks & Bonds

sections.title: Understanding Securities
sections.content:
Investing is the act of allocating resources, usually money, with the expectation of generating an income or profit.

- **Security**: A tradable financial asset (shares, bonds).
- **Equity / Stocks / Shares**: Units of ownership in a company. If the company grows, the share value increases.
- **Dividends**: A portion of a company's profit paid to shareholders.
- **Bonds**: Debt instruments where you lend money to an organization (government or corporate) for a fixed period at a fixed interest rate.
- **Maturity**: The date when a bond must be repaid.
- **Portfolio**: A collection of financial investments held by an individual or institution.

sections.title: Risk and Return
sections.content:
The fundamental principle of investing is the relationship between risk and reward:

- **Asset Allocation**: Dividing an investment portfolio among different asset categories (stocks, bonds, cash).
- **Diversification**: Spreading investments to reduce risk ("Don't put all your eggs in one basket").
- **Volatility**: The rate at which the price of a security increases or decreases.
- **Bull Market**: A market where prices are rising or expected to rise.
- **Bear Market**: A market where prices are falling.

sections.title: Grammar Focus: First Conditional
sections.content:
We use the first conditional to talk about real possibilities and their consequences in the future market.

- If the stock price **rises**, I **will sell** my shares. (Si el precio de la acción sube, venderé mis acciones).
- If the interest rates **go up**, bond prices **will fall**. (Si los tipos de interés suben, los precios de los bonos caerán).
- We **will not invest** if the risk **is** too high. (No invertiremos si el riesgo es demasiado alto).

**Structure**: If + **Present Simple**, + **Will** + verb.
